fields.Title of Contribution: Scale Free Projections Arise from Bipartite Random Networks
fields.Journal: International Journal of Data Science and Analytics
fields.Description/Abstract: The degree distribution of a real world network — the number of links per node<br>— often follows a power law, so some hubs have many more links than traditional<br>graph generation methods predict. For years, preferential attachment and growth<br>have been the proposed mechanisms that lead to these scale free networks. How-<br>ever, when two sides of bipartite graphs like collaboration networks are not scale<br>free, they are not well-explained by these processes. Here we develop a bipar-<br>tite extension to the Randomly Stopped Linking Model for generating networks<br>and show that mixtures of geometric distributions can lead to power laws, an<br>intuition suggested by the Central Limit Theorem for distributions with infinite<br>variance. We show that the two halves of the actor-movie network are not scale<br>free and can be represented by just 6 geometric distributions, but they combine<br>to form a scale free actor-actor unipartite projection without preferential attach-<br>ment or growth. This result supports our claim that scale free networks are the<br>natural result of many Bernoulli trials with high variance of which preferential<br>attachment and growth are only one example.
